Hi John,

Try taking a look at the Holt-Winters aberrant behavior detection=
 algorithm
in rrdtool. There's a summary here:
http://cricket.sourceforge.n=
et/aberrant/rrd_hw.htm

I think it's made for something pretty close to the=
 situation you describe.

On Tue, Mar 15, 2011 at 7:32 PM, John Arrowwood <=
jarrowwx@...> wrote:

>
>
> Just want to pick the group's brain about=
 something:
>
> I'm working on a team that has produced a WebService layer.=
  This layer is
> an abstraction layer between clients (web and IVR) and th=
e back-end billing
> systems.  The logs for this product are immense.  They=
 log the inputs and
> outputs for every call coming in to the layer, and an=
other log entry for
> every call out to the external dependencies.
>
> In t=
his iteration that just completed, I started work on a script to parse
> th=
ose logs and look for instances where exceptions were raised as responses
>=
 to requests.  The intention is to alert the team in the event that there a=
re
> ever an unusual amount of activity.  I was thinking that the IDEAL thi=
ng
> would be if this script were to learn the definition of "normal" and o=
nly
> alert when something truly abnormal took place.
>
> Here's the thing:=
  the definition of "normal" changes by the hour, and by
> the day.  Monday=
s are typically the busiest days, and it falls off as the
> week progresses=
.  Holidays can alter that.  The 1st and the 15th also seem
> to influence =
it.  Around the noon hour is a peak time, and after around 5 it
> goes back=
 up, and then falls off again in the late evening.  The things that
> peopl=
e call for also change depending on the time of day or the day of
> week.  =
So the definition of "normal" is highly complex.  Too complex,
> really, to=
 manually model it.
>
> As a first-stab at it, I just created "floating thr=
esholds" that rise or
> fall a little bit whenever the actual is significan=
tly over or under the
> current threshold.  This seems to kind of work, but=
 I'm not satisfied with
> it.
>
> What I would like to see is an unsupervis=
ed learning algorithm.  I break
> down the logs into the bits and pieces ne=
cessary for it to "learn" the
> definition of normal, and then have it tell=
 me how "normal" it thinks it
> is.  But it has to learn the definition of =
"normal" from data that is not
> always normal.  I don't want to have to tr=
y to come up with training data by
> pulling out the "abnormal" data.  I do=
n't want to have to tell it if it is
> right or not for every one of the mi=
llions of log entries per day over the
> several months of data that I woul=
d need in order for it to understand what
> "normal" is.
>
> Do any of you =
have any ideas about how Neat might be applied in a problem
> domain like t=
his?  Or are there other Machine Learning techniques that would
> be more a=
pplicable to this problem?
>
> Thanks for any feedback you might have!
>
> =
--
> John Arrowwood
> http://www.FindingResonance.com/ - blog
> http://www.=
TransformativeTherapiesInc.com/
> http://www.irie-inc.com/
>
>
>  
>

--485b395e7ae9842e95049e8ec011

Hi John,<div><br></div><div>Try taking a look at the Holt-Winters aberrant =
behavior detection algorithm in rrdtool. There's a summary here: <a hre=
f=3D"http://cricket.sourceforge.net/aberrant/rrd_hw.htm">http://cricket.sou=
rceforge.net/aberrant/rrd_hw.htm</a></div>

<div><br></div><div>I think it&=
#39;s made for something pretty close to the situation you describe.</div><=
div><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Tue, Mar 15, 2011 at 7:32 PM, John Ar=
rowwood <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:jarrowwx@...">jarroww=
x@...</a>></span> wrote:<br>

<blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" st=
yle=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padding-left:1ex;">



=










<div style=3D"background-color:#fff">
<span>=A0</span>


<div>
  =
<div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p>Just want to pick the group's =
brain about something:<br><br>I'm working on a team that has produced a=
 WebService layer.=A0 This layer is an abstraction layer between clients (w=
eb and IVR) and the back-end billing systems.=A0 The logs for this product =
are immense.=A0 They log the inputs and outputs for every call coming in to=
 the layer, and another log entry for every call out to the external depend=
encies.<br>



<br>In this iteration that just completed, I started work on=
 a script to parse those logs and look for instances where exceptions were =
raised as responses to requests.=A0 The intention is to alert the team in t=
he event that there are ever an unusual amount of activity.=A0 I was thinki=
ng that the IDEAL thing would be if this script were to learn the definitio=
n of "normal" and only alert when something truly abnormal took p=
lace.<br>



<br>Here's the thing:=A0 the definition of "normal&qu=
ot; changes by the hour, and by the day.=A0 Mondays are typically the busie=
st days, and it falls off as the week progresses.=A0 Holidays can alter tha=
t.=A0 The 1st and the 15th also seem to influence it.=A0 Around the noon ho=
ur is a peak time, and after around 5 it goes back up, and then falls off a=
gain in the late evening.=A0 The things that people call for also change de=
pending on the time of day or the day of week.=A0 So the definition of &quo=
t;normal" is highly complex.=A0 Too complex, really, to manually model=
 it.<br>



<br>As a first-stab at it, I just created "floating thresh=
olds" that rise or fall a little bit whenever the actual is significan=
tly over or under the current threshold.=A0 This seems to kind of work, but=
 I'm not satisfied with it.<br>



<br>What I would like to see is an u=
nsupervised learning algorithm.=A0 I break down the logs into the bits and =
pieces necessary for it to "learn" the definition of normal, and =
then have it tell me how "normal" it thinks it is.=A0 But it has =
to learn the definition of "normal" from data that is not always =
normal.=A0 I don't want to have to try to come up with training data by=
 pulling out the "abnormal" data.=A0 I don't want to have to =
tell it if it is right or not for every one of the millions of log entries =
per day over the several months of data that I would need in order for it t=
o understand what "normal" is.=A0 <br>



<br>Do any of you have =
any ideas about how Neat might be applied in a problem domain like this?=A0=
 Or are there other Machine Learning techniques that would be more applicab=
le to this problem?<br><br>Thanks for any feedback you might have!<br>



<=
br>-- <br>John Arrowwood<br><a href=3D"http://www.FindingResonance.com/" ta=
rget=3D"_blank">http://www.FindingResonance.com/</a> - blog<br><a href=3D"h=
ttp://www.TransformativeTherapiesInc.com/" target=3D"_blank">http://www.Tra=
nsformativeTherapiesInc.com/</a><br>



<a href=3D"http://www.irie-inc.com/=
" target=3D"_blank">http://www.irie-inc.com/</a><br><br><br>
</p>

    </di=
v>
